utterances: Yes, it's exactly right.
And also, outside a soup market, there was a line of over 1,000 people.
And they were just buying flour, milk, real basics.
And this is something they told me that's been going on for a year at least.
You're also seeing inflation, which is one of the highest figures in the Americas at least.
And that's at 56.3 percent over the last year.
(Unintelligible) crime.
This is one of the most violent countries in the world.
According to NGOs, around 70 people are killed here every single day.
And that, for about the same population, is double the number of people killed in Iraq.
Who are the people protesting in the streets, and what do they want?
We'll be going into a recession the next couple of years.
I think the question is, when?
If that recession comes before the election, I think, absolutely, it's going to be a major political headwind, if you will.
If it comes afterwards, it's going to benefit, I think, the current administration.
His advice - just because you have credit available to you doesn't mean you should use it.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
And some news from the art world now.
The secretive artist Banksy is known for the political street art he paints in cities around the world.
On Friday night, one of his paintings of a small girl and a heart-shaped red balloon just out of reach went to auction at Sotheby's in London and sold for almost $1.4 million.
But the room and, presumably, the painting's anonymous buyer were in for a surprise.
I asked New York magazine's art critic Jerry Saltz to explain.
As it was being sold, and the hammer went down over $1 million, suddenly, it started to rumble and buzz, and the canvas sort of disappeared down into the frame and came out beneath it shredded.
It was fantastic.
What was the reaction?
Well, I think people were horrified, amazed, shocked.
The market is such a kind of dumb organism.
People in the market buy what other people in the market buy.
And suddenly, one of the things they are buying changed.
So he pranked them.
Maybe it is only a prank, but, God, it felt good.
Do we know if Sotheby's had an idea that this was going to happen and, of course, the person who spent quite a bit of money on the artwork?
I don't know.
The shock of it is part of what makes it good.
But I like that, somehow, an artist - an artist that I don't necessarily like - really was able to disrupt the system, if only for a minute.
I know you don't like the idea of the market and how influential it is on artists' work.
But will this work now be even more valuable, even shredded, because it has garnered so much attention?
Well, that's the insidious thing about it, isn't it?
- that the market, as I say, only buys what other people in the market have bought.
So now everyone will want a shredded Banksy.
Pulitzer Prize-winning writer Jerry Saltz from New York magazine, thank you very much.
Pleasure.
(SOUNDBITE OF ANTI-LILLY AND PHONIKS SONG, ""LOOSE PRAYERS"")
Apple and other retailers did terribly last month.
Retail sales were off 2.7 percent.
That was a lot lower than analysts had predicted.
Some chain stores are trying hard now to lure immigrant shoppers.
From member station KJZZ in Phoenix, Rene Gutel reports.
Shoppers mingled the aisles of this brightly colored department store in West Phoenix.
All designs in the store are in Spanish, and Spanish language music is blaring from stereos.
Customer Jesus Navarro(ph), who's originally from Mexico City, says he comes here often.
(Through Translator) We find a lot of items from our country.
And the deals they have, the prices they have, seem really affordable.
Welcome to La Curacao, a California-based chain of stores that caters exclusively to Hispanics.
They sell the usual furniture, computer goods, and jewelry.
But they also have unique services.
For instance, there's a counter where you can wire money to Latin America.
Michael Segovia is the store manager.
And he says every aspect of the shopping experience, right down to the music, is carefully planned.
Hispanic families like music.
They liked to be entertained.
So we have live entertainment on the weekends, and we play music just about everywhere, so customers can see - feel that Hispanic atmosphere in our store.
In a time when some major retailers are closing stores and scaling back operations, La Curacao is growing.
This store opened in late 2007, the first in Arizona.
And another like Curacao is slated to open in the Phoenix area this summer.
I think that companies across America are finally realizing the growing Hispanic market with an increasing purchasing power, four times that of any other group in America.
Louis Olivas is a professor at Arizona State University's W.P.
Carey School of Business.
He says the increase is due to Latino population growth and something else.
In a recent study, he looked at Hispanics in the state of Arizona and says they have the highest labor rate, greater than any other race.
They have a larger participation rate proportioned to the population and more wage earners in the household.
Meaning, they have more than one job.
And so that's critical in a growing purchasing power by the Hispanic market.
In recent years, chains like Best Buy and Wal-Mart have been steadily ramping up their efforts to market to immigrant communities and compete with stores like La Curacao.
For example, Wal-Mart has translated parts of its Web site into Spanish as well as Chinese and Vietnamese.
And Best Buy has a fully functional Spanish-English Web site.
Hello.
Welcome to Best Buy.
Hello.
How are you doing?
At a Best Buy in central Phoenix, there's a long overflowing isle of Spanish language music.
And every sign here is in Spanish, too.
Cesar Figueroa(ph) is a store manager.
It's just happens to be in Spanish here in our market.

But if you go throughout the country, you'll see that Best Buy really tries to reflect the community, so you'll see Polish signs out in Polish-strong communities, Russian signs in Russian-strong communities.
These are efforts the company began long before the recession hit, but they could pay extra dividends now.
Figueroa says it's important for store employees to be aware of the way that many Latinos approach shopping.
It's not one person that comes in to buy the TV.
You get the whole family that comes in to buy the TV.
It's an event.
Figueroa is standing near the video games section when two men approach him and ask in Spanish whether there are any Nintendo Wiis for sale.
Figueroa doesn't miss a beat.
The people protesting here in Caracas are generally the middle classes.
But across the country, you are seeing a different demographic of protesting.
You're seeing people who are working classes, seeing older people, not just students.
Now, what do they want?
Well, that's the big question.
I keep asking them this, and they want change.
They want an end to the government of President Nicolas Maduro and the socialists that was brought about by Hugo Chavez 15 years ago.
But there's no real way for them to achieve that right now.
In two years, there's a chance for a referendum, which the opposition could, of course, win, but that's two years away.
They want some change a lot sooner.
Earlier this week, you were in San Cristobal near the border of Colombia.
What is it like there compared to what you've seen in Caracas?
The city of San Cristobal is essentially under siege.
But by its own residents, on every street corner, you see a burning barricade of trash, and an armored vehicle has been set alight and blocks the road there.
All the shops are closed, all the restaurants are closed.
It's very difficult to move about within the city.
Teenagers strut around with slingshots, with petrol bombs.
And so it's a very different scene to what we're seeing in Caracas.
However, the aims are the same and the problems essentially, the economy, the crime remain the same.
Venezuela is Latin America's biggest exporter of crude oil.
In January, the country produced 2.5 million barrels a day.
Much of that was coming to the U.S.
Is there a concern that the situation there, the unrest could affect the oil industry?
Now, in 2002, towards the end of that year, there was a major oil strike, which completely crippled the oil supply at this country.
And it lasted about two or three months back then.
Now, what happens after that 2002 event was that Chavez and the government sacked half the workforce and replaced them with government supporters.
And that's still the case now.
So it's very unlikely they'll go on strike, but it's, of course, a possibility and a means to re-cripple this government.
That's reporter Girish Gupta who's been covering the protests in Venezuela.
Girish, thank you.
Thank you.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
Just imagine how tough life would be if raindrops weighed three tons apiece as they fell out of the sky at 20 miles an hour.
Well, that's how raindrops seem to a mosquito.
So, how do they survive a downpour?
NPR's Richard Harris has the answer.
Put yourself in a mosquito's shoes for a moment - or rain boots - and step outside into a downpour of seemingly gigantic raindrops.
So they're basically, like plummeting comets falling all around you.
You'd think a mosquito wouldn't stand a chance.
That's what David Hu and his colleagues at Georgia Tech thought.
We expected a similar thing to happen as when you drive a car through bugs; you expect to see this bug just splattering.
Yet mosquitoes clearly survive close encounters with raindrops.
The question is how.
So David Hu's group set out to run an experiment that made the most of their skills as mechanical engineers and biologists.
